{
  "overview": "The purpose of this bill is to facilitate more effective enforcement of Hawaii’s fireworks control laws by amending definitions, strengthening and clarifying criminal offenses, and establishing new offenses. [CHUNK_10] The establishment of an adjudication system and procedures to process fireworks infractions represents a significant step forward in addressing the ongoing challenges of illegal fireworks in Hawaii. [CHUNK_2] This bill provides a more robust framework for enforcement and accountability. [CHUNK_3]",
  "appropriations": "",
  "assumptions_and_methodology": "",
  "agency_impact": "The Department of Law Enforcement (DLE) supports the bill but is concerned about the potential repeal of provisions that relate to the DLE’s ability to assist fire departments with conducting inspections of fireworks licenses. [CHUNK_4, CHUNK_5] Last year, the Legislature acted to give the DLE authority to assist the county fire departments with inspections of fireworks licenses, and the DLE believes that this authority is still needed. [CHUNK_6, CHUNK_7] The Department of the Attorney General strongly supports this bill and proposes amendments to strengthen its legislative intent, such as adding an offense for throwing or manually propelling ignited fireworks. [CHUNK_10]",
  "economic_impact": "",
  "policy_impact": "Your Committee has amended this measure by amending the offense of general fireworks or articles pyrotechnic prohibitions in the second degree. [CHUNK_24, CHUNK_34] This amendment includes throwing, catapulting, or otherwise manually propelling ignited aerial devices, articles pyrotechnics, consumer fireworks, or display fireworks as part of the offense. [CHUNK_24, CHUNK_35] The committee also clarified when the state of mind requirement is not applicable for this offense and clarified the weight thresholds for certain penalties. [CHUNK_35, CHUNK_36]",
  "revenue_sources": "Revenue for this measure will be generated through fines. [CHUNK_11] For a first offense, the carrier or person shall be subject to a $1,000 (HB1483_HD1_.HTM.txt) fine. [CHUNK_3] For a second offense committed within five years of a prior judgment, the fine is $2,000 (HB1483_HD1_.HTM.txt), and for a third or subsequent offense, the fine is $5,000 (HB1483_HD1_.HTM.txt). [CHUNK_4, CHUNK_5] Other violations of this chapter shall be fined no less than $500 (HB1483_HD1_.HTM.txt) and no more than $5,000 (HB1483_HD1_.HTM.txt) for each violation. [CHUNK_9, CHUNK_8]",
  "six_year_fiscal_implications": "",
  "operating_revenue_impact": "The measure is expected to generate operating revenue from penalties for fireworks offenses. [CHUNK_11] These penalties include a $1,000 (HB1483_HD1_.HTM.txt) fine for a first offense, a $2,000 (HB1483_HD1_.HTM.txt) fine for a second offense, and a $5,000 (HB1483_HD1_.HTM.txt) fine for a third offense. [CHUNK_3, CHUNK_4, CHUNK_5] Other violations are subject to a fine of no less than $500 (HB1483_HD1_.HTM.txt) and no more than $5,000 (HB1483_HD1_.HTM.txt). [CHUNK_9, CHUNK_8]",
  "capital_expenditure_impact": "",
  "fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "",
  "updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "New testimony from the Department of Law Enforcement (DLE) expresses concern regarding the potential repeal of its authority to assist with fireworks license inspections. [CHUNK_5] The Department of the Attorney General provided testimony with specific recommendations for amendments to strengthen the bill's intent. [CHUNK_10] The Judiciary & Hawaiian Affairs Committee made specific amendments to the offense of general fireworks or articles pyrotechnic prohibitions in the second degree, including adding the act of throwing or manually propelling ignited fireworks. [CHUNK_24, CHUNK_35] The source document for the specified fine amounts has been updated to HB1483_HD1_.HTM.txt. [CHUNK_3, CHUNK_4, CHUNK_5, CHUNK_8, CHUNK_9]"
}

more common-sense standards; (2) strengthening and clarifying existing criminal offenses; (3) establishing new offenses; (4) establishing heightened penalties for repeat offenders and offenses that result in substantial or serious bodily injury or death; and (5) establishing non- criminal fireworks infractions for the lowest-level offenses. for the lowest-level offenses. Criminal statutes serve as a deterrent to illegal activity when they are effectively enforced and prosecuted. enforce or prosecute these types of cases. No. 1483 entitled:

No. 1483 entitled: "A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO FIREWORKS," begs leave to report as follows: The purpose of this measure is to: (1) Establish an adjudication system and procedures to process fireworks infractions; (2) Amend and establish various definitions and penalties

fireworks infractions; (2) Amend and establish various definitions and penalties for fireworks offenses, including establishing heightened penalties under certain circumstances; (3) Establish various criminal offenses and penalties related to fireworks or articles pyrotechnics; and (4) Appropriate funds. Your Committee received testimony in support of this measure from the Department of

testimony in support of this measure from the Department of Law Enforcement; Department of the Attorney General; Honolulu Police Department; Hawaiian Humane Society; Animal Interfaith Alliance in Britain; and numerous individuals. Your Committee received testimony in opposition to this measure from Hawaii Pyrotechnics and Explosives LLC; Libertarian Party of Hawaii;

from Hawaii Pyrotechnics and Explosives LLC; Libertarian Party of Hawaii; and three individuals. Your Committee finds that it has been difficult for state and county agencies to enforce or prosecute illegal fireworks cases in the State due to challenges with gathering evidence, meeting the high burden of proof necessary for

gathering evidence, meeting the high burden of proof necessary for convictions, and stringent definitions. This measure would largely address the concerns raised by prosecutors and provide greater clarity and efficiency for law enforcement, prosecutors, and the courts. Your Committee has amended this measure by: (1) Amending the offense of general

amended this measure by: (1) Amending the offense of general fireworks or articles pyrotechnic prohibitions in the second degree to: (A) Include throwing, catapulting, or otherwise manually propelling ignited aerial devices, articles pyrotechnics, consumer fireworks, or display fireworks; and (B) Clarify when the state of mind requirement is not applicable;

Clarify when the state of mind requirement is not applicable; (2) Clarifying the definitions of "aerial device", "consumer fireworks", and "fireworks"; (3) Clarifying the weight thresholds for certain penalties for fireworks offenses; (4) Restoring the authority of law enforcement officers to conduct inspections to verify compliance with fireworks laws; (5)

to conduct inspections to verify compliance with fireworks laws; (5) Changing the effective date to July 1, 3000, to encourage further discussion ; and (6) Making technical, nonsubstantive amendments for the purposes of clarity, consistency, and style. the record of votes of the members of your Committee on Judiciary & Hawaiian Affairs that is attached to this report, your Committee is in accord with the intent and purpose of H.B. No. 1483, as amended herein, and recommends that it pass Second Reading in the form attached hereto

Hawaiian Affairs, to which was referred H.B. No. 1483 entitled: "A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO FIREWORKS," begs leave to report as follows: The purpose of this measure is to: (1) Establish an adjudication system and procedures to process fireworks infractions; (2) Amend and establish various definitions and penalties

fireworks infractions; (2) Amend and establish various definitions and penalties for fireworks offenses, including establishing heightened penalties under certain circumstances; (3) Establish various criminal offenses and penalties related to fireworks or articles pyrotechnics; and (4) Appropriate funds. Your Committee received testimony in support of this measure from the Department of

testimony in support of this measure from the Department of Law Enforcement; Department of the Attorney General; Honolulu Police Department; Hawaiian Humane Society; Animal Interfaith Alliance in Britain; and numerous individuals. Your Committee received testimony in opposition to this measure from Hawaii Pyrotechnics and Explosives LLC; Libertarian Party of Hawaii;

from Hawaii Pyrotechnics and Explosives LLC; Libertarian Party of Hawaii; and three individuals. Your Committee finds that it has been difficult for state and county agencies to enforce or prosecute illegal fireworks cases in the State due to challenges with gathering evidence, meeting the high burden of proof necessary for

gathering evidence, meeting the high burden of proof necessary for convictions, and stringent definitions. This measure would largely address the concerns raised by prosecutors and provide greater clarity and efficiency for law enforcement, prosecutors, and the courts. Your Committee has amended this measure by: (1) Amending the offense of general

amended this measure by: (1) Amending the offense of general fireworks or articles pyrotechnic prohibitions in the second degree to: (A) Include throwing, catapulting, or otherwise manually propelling ignited aerial devices, articles pyrotechnics, consumer fireworks, or display fireworks; and (B) Clarify when the state of mind requirement is not applicable;

Clarify when the state of mind requirement is not applicable; (2) Clarifying the definitions of "aerial device", "consumer fireworks", and "fireworks"; (3) Clarifying the weight thresholds for certain penalties for fireworks offenses; (4) Restoring the authority of law enforcement officers to conduct inspections to verify compliance with fireworks laws; (5)

to conduct inspections to verify compliance with fireworks laws; (5) Changing the effective date to July 1, 3000, to encourage further discussion ; and (6) Making technical, nonsubstantive amendments for the purposes of clarity, consistency, and style. the record of votes of the members of your Committee on Judiciary & Hawaiian Affairs that is attached to this report, your Committee is in accord with the intent and purpose of H.B. No. 1483, as amended herein, and recommends that it pass Second Reading in the form attached hereto
